dataset.title: Long term limnological measures in Acton Lake, a southwest Ohio reservoir, and its inflow streams: 1992-2017

abstract.para: Long-term data were collected from Acton Lake and its inflow streams, on a suite of physical, chemical and biological variables. The data are collected as part of long-term research investigating how Acton Lake, a eutrophic reservoir, responds to changes in ecosystem subsidies of detritus (sediments) and nutrients. Our data span 26 years, from 1992-2017, although for some parameters the data set spans a shorter time frame within this period. In three of Acton Lake's inflow streams, collectively constituting ~86% of the lake's watershed, we include data on hourly stream discharge, as well as concentrations of suspended sediments, ammonium-nitrogen (N), nitrate-N, and soluble reactive phosphorus (P). Data on the concentrations of these constituents were collected at various time scales depending on stream discharge (usually every 6-8 hours during storms, every 1-3 days during baseflow). In Acton Lake, we collected data on several parameters from an "outflow" site, at the deepest part of the lake where there is usually stable thermal stratification in summer. Vertical profile data were collected for temperature, dissolved oxygen, and "light" (photosynthetically active radiation, PAR). Depth profile data were collected at 0.5 or 1 m intervals (depending on depth and year), usually from April or May until September or October. In addition, data for several parameters were obtained from "integrated samples" that collect water from the lake surface to the bottom of the euphotic zone (defined as the depth at which PAR equals 1% of PAR at the surface) with a tube or pump. Parameters for which integrated data are presented include chlorophyll; suspended solids; non-volatile suspended solids; particulate (seston) carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus; and total nitrogen and total phosphorus. We also collected Secchi depth data, using standard methods. Larval fish were collected in the top 2 meters of the water column with a metered net to generate estimates of larval fish density. Finally, zooplankton were collected by towing a net vertically through the water column; we present data on total zooplankton biomass here.

intellectualRights.para: This data package is released to the “public domain” under Creative Commons CC0 1.0 “No Rights Reserved” (see: https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). It is considered professional etiquette to provide attribution of the original work if this data package is shared in whole or by individual components. A generic citation is provided for this data package on the website https://portal.edirepository.org (herein “website”) in the summary metadata page. Communication (and collaboration) with the creators of this data package is recommended to prevent duplicate research or publication. This data package (and its components) is made available “as is” and with no warranty of accuracy or fitness for use. The creators of this data package and the website shall not be liable for any damages resulting from misinterpretation or misuse of the data package or its components. Periodic updates of this data package may be available from the website. Thank you.

description.para: Consistency in methods was maintained as much as possible; however, for some parameters, different models of instruments, or different sensors, were used over the course of the study. When methods or instruments were switched, comparisons (and intercalibrations where necessary) of old and new methods/ instruments were done to ensure consistency in data throughout the data set.

Stream data Samples were collected from Acton Lake's the three major streams: Little Four Mile, Four Mile, and Marshall's Branch. Samples were collected at gaging stations installed just upstream of where the streams enter Acton Lake. In each stream, discharge (volume of water flowing by the site per unit time) was estimated by measuring stream stage every 10 minutes with a pressure transducer. At various times, stream discharge measured directly with a flow meter and regressed against stream stage to generate a rating curve. The rating curve was used to estimate discharge every 10 minutes, and these values were averaged to yield hourly discharge (presented in this file). Water samples used to measure concentrations of suspended solids (SS) and dissolved nutrients were collected using ISCO samplers that automatically pump a sample at specified intervals. For most of the study period, samples were collected at 7 hour intervals, but in some of the early years the interval ranged from 2-8 hours. During storms, all samples were processed for nutrients and SS, but during baseflow periods only 1-3 samples per week were processed. The ISCO sampler stores 24 samples in polyethylene bottles, which were collected and returned to the lab for processing on a weekly basis.

Suspended solids (SS) concentrations were quantified on stream samples by filtering a known volume through pre-weighed, pre-ashed 47 mm diameter glass fiber Pall AE filters, which were then folded, wrapped in aluminum foil and frozen. Filters were later thawed, dried at 60_C to constant mass in a drying oven, and re-weighed. The mass of SS was obtained as the difference in mass between the pre-weighed filter and the filter (plus sample) after drying.

Dissolved inorganic nutrients, including ammonium-nitrogen, nitrate-nitrogen and soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP), were measured on stream samples. In the lab, samples were filtered through glass fiber filters (Pall AE). The filtrate was saved in a polyethylene bottle, acidified to pH ~2 with sulfuric acid, and stored at ~5_C until samples were analyzed. From 1994-1998, dissolved nutrients were analyzed manually, whereas from 1999 onwards they were analyzed with a Lachat FIA 8000 (1999-2013) or 8500 (2014-present) auto-analyzer. Throughout the study, ammonium-N was analyzed using the phenol-hypochlorite method, and SRP with the molybdenum blue method. Nitrate-N (actually nitrate plus nitrite) was analyzed using second-derivative spectroscopy through 1998 and with the cadmium reduction method from 1999 onwards. As described in Renwick et al. (2008), we ran samples using both manual and auto-analyzer methods, and found that they gave very similar results, but nevertheless we converted all concentrations to auto-analyzer values using the equations: Nitrate(A)= 22.3 + 0.932Nitrate(M) (r^2=0.994); Ammonium(A) = -0.509 + 1.022Ammonium(M) (r^2=0.991); SRP(A)= 0.112 + 0.964*SRP(M) (r^2=0.994).

Lake data Integrated sample depth is the approximate depth of the bottom of the euphotic zone, defined as the depth at which photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) was equal to 1% of surface PAR. Integrated sample depth was estimated in the field using PAR data, and then samples were collected from the lake surface to the bottom of the euphotic zone, by lowering a weighted tube that trapped a column of water, or with a battery-powered pump. All data presented in this file were taken at our 'Outflow' site, which is located at the deepest part of the lake, near the dam, where there is usually stable thermal stratification in summer.

Secchi depth was measured by lowering a black and white Secchi disk into the lake until it disappeared from view, then raising the disk until it reappeared. Secchi depth is defined as the mean of the depths at which the disk disappeared and reappeared.

Temperature and dissolved oxygen were measured with a YSI Model 58 (exclusively in years prior to 2006) or Pro ODO (used for the majority of temperature and dissolved oxygen measurements from 2007-present).
Light (photosynthetically active radiation, PAR) was measured with a Licor photometer with an underwater spherical quantum sensor (model LI-189).

Chlorophyll a was quantified by collecting an integrated water sample from integrated sample depth, i.e., from the lake surface to the bottom of the euphotic zone. Integrated samples were collected by lowering a weighted tube that trapped a column of water, or with a battery-powered pump moved throughout the euphotic zone. In the lab, samples of known volume were collected onto glass fiber filters (47 mm diameter Pall AE), placed in film canisters and frozen. Samples were then thawed and 25 mL of either acetone (through 2009) or 95% ethanol (from 2010 onwards) was added to the film canister to extract chlorophyll. Chlorophyll was extracted for 4-24 hours at ~5_C in the dark and measured on a Turner model TD-700 fluorometer. In 2010 we analyzed approximately 58 samples from three lakes (Acton, Burr Oak and Pleasant Hill, all in Ohio, USA) using both methods and verified that the methods gave nearly identical results; nevertheless, pre-2010 chlorophyll values were converted to the ethanol-based method using the equation (Chl(E)= 2.062 + 0.958Chl(A) (r^2=0.992), where Chl(E) and Chl(A) are chlorophyll concentrations using ethanol and acetone, respectively.

Suspended solids (SS) and non-volatile suspended solids (NVSS) were quantified from integrated samples. SS concentrations were quantified by filtering a known volume through pre-weighed, pre-ashed 47 mm diameter glass fiber Pall AE filters, which were folded, wrapped in aluminum foil and frozen. Filters were later thawed, dried at 60_C to constant mass in a drying oven, and re-weighed. The mass of SS was obtained as the difference in mass between the pre-weighed filter and the filter (plus sample) after drying. To estimate NVSS concentration, the filter was then ashed in a muffle furnace at 550_C for 4 hours, and weighed again. The mass of NVSS, which represents inorganic particles such as silt and clay, was obtained as the difference in mass of the pre-weighed filter and the filter after ashing.

Total nitrogen (N) and total phosphorus (P) concentrations were measured on integrated samples, collected in the same manner as chlorophyll, described above. On the lake, samples were placed in Nalgene bottles that were stored in a cooler. In the lab, unfiltered samples for total N and total P were simply placed in polyethylene bottles, acidified to pH ~2 with sulfuric acid, and stored at ~5_C until analysis. To quantify total N, from 1994-2012 we digested samples with low-N potassium persulfate, which converts all N to nitrate, and quantified nitrate concentration using second derivative spectroscopy on a Varian DMS 100S UV/VIS spectrophotometer (1994-2004) or Perkin Elmer Lambda 35 UV/VIS spectrophotometer (2005-2012). From 2013 onwards, we digested samples using a low-N potassium persulfate - boric acid digestion reagent, and analyzed nitrate using the cadmium reduction method on a Lachat FIA 8500 auto-analyzer. To quantify total P samples were digested with potassium persulfate to convert all P to SRP, and analyzed as with the stream SRP samples.

Particulate (seston) carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) concentrations were measured on integrated samples, collected as described above for chlorophyll, and also passed through a 63 micrometer mesh net to remove most zooplankton prior to preservation. For particulate C and N, a sample of known volume was collected on a 10 mm Pall AE glass fiber filter, wrapped in foil, and frozen. For particulate P, a sample of known volume was collected on a 47 mm diameter Pall AE glass fiber filter, which was stored at room temperature in a 20 mL glass vial. Particulate C and N were analyzed with a Perkin Elmer Series 2400 (1992-2009) or a CE Elantech Flash 200 CHN analyzer (2010-present). Particulate P samples were ashed in a muffle furnace, then digested with HCl to convert all P to SRP, which was analyzed with the molybdenum blue method as described above.

Zooplankton biomass was quantified in 1996 and 1997 by taking samples with a Schindler-Patalas trap (53 micrometer mesh) at 1-meter depth increments (0-8 m, one sample per depth). From 1998 to present, samples were obtained from a single vertical tow taken from a known depth (presented in this data set as ZooplanktonDepth) to the surface, using a conical, 53 micrometer mesh plankton net. Upon collection, zooplankton were immediately anesthetized with effervescing CO2 tablets, and preserved with a buffered formalin solution (5% of final sample volume). In 1996 and 1997, when depth-specific samples were collected, samples from all depths were pooled to yield a single sample. Zooplankton taxa were identified using a compound (rotifers) or dissecting (crustacean) microscope, in at least two subsamples per sample. Individuals were identified to the finest taxonomic resolution possible and counted, and a subsample of individuals was measured. For crustaceans, individual dry mass was obtained using published length-dry mass equations. For rotifers, we applied geometric formulas that approximate the shape of individuals to obtain individual volumes, then volume was converted to wet mass assuming a specific gravity of 1, and to dry mass assuming a dry:wet mass ratio of 0.1. The biomass of each taxon was obtained as the number of individuals per L of lake water times mean individual dry mass, then these were summed to obtain total zooplankton dry mass (micrograms per L of lake water).

Larval fish density was obtained by towing either a either a circular ichthyoplankton net (0.5 mm mesh, 0.75 m diameter, 2 m length) in 1996, 1997 and 2001, or, in other years, with a rectangular neuston net (0.5 mm mesh, 1 x 2 m wide mouth). We sampled larvae along two transects (two samples/transect). Each sample was a ~3 min tow at 1 m s-1, except when high zooplankton densities necessitated shorter tows. Both nets were equipped with a flow meter mounted at the mouth of the net, which provided an estimate of volume sampled. During 2002 and 2003, we collected samples with both nets, and a calibration factor was used to adjust all larval density estimates to neuston net values. Immediately after capture, larval fish were preserved in 10% formalin or 95% ethanol. Larvae were identified using a dissecting microscope, but here we present total larval fish density (i.e., all species). Densities are presented as individuals per m3 in the top 0-2 m of the lake (the depth over which larvae were sampled).
Renwick, WH, MJ Vanni, Q Zhang and J Patton. 2008. Water quality trends and changing agricultural practices in a Midwest US watershed, 1994-2006. Journal of Environmental Quality 37:1862-1874.

dataTable.entityDescription: Depth-specific data from the outflow site, deepest part of Acton Lake

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of lake or stream from which measurement was taken.

textDomain.definition: Name of lake or stream from which measurement was taken.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date on which sample was collected.
Depth below the surface of the lake from which measurement was taken.
Concentration of dissolved oxygen, measured every 0.5 - 1 m in the water column.
Light intensity (photosynthetically active radiation, PAR), measured every 0.5 - 1 m in the water column.
Water temperature, measured every 0.5 - 1 m in the water column.

dataTable.entityDescription: Lake data from samples integrated through a portion of the water column at the outflow site of Acton Lake

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of lake or stream from which measurement was taken.

textDomain.definition: Name of lake or stream from which measurement was taken.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date on which sample was collected.

Secchi depth was measured by lowering a black and white Secchi disk into the lake until it disappeared from view, then raising the disk until it reappeared. Secchi depth is defined as the mean of the depths at which the disk disappeared and reappeared.
Measure of the density of larval gizzard shad, estimated from larval fish collected from tows along transects between 0-2 meters depth in the lake.

Approximate depth of the bottom of the euphotic zone, estimated in the field. The bottom of the euphotic zone was estimated as the depth at which photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) was equal to 1% of surface PAR. Integrated samples were collected from the lake surface to the bottom of the euphotic zone.
Measure of chlorophyll-a concentration in a water sample integrated over the euphotic zone of the lake (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth").
Concentration of particulate matter (organic and inorganic) in a water sample integrated over the euphotic zone of the lake (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth").
Concentration of inorganic particulate matter in a water sample integrated over the euphotic zone of the lake (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth").
Carbon concentration in seston from a water sample integrated over the euphotic zone of the lake (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth") and passed through a 63 micrometer mesh.
Nitrogen concentration in seston from a water sample integrated over the euphotic zone of the lake (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth") and passed through a 63 micrometer mesh.
Phosphorus concentration in seston from a water sample integrated over the euphotic zone of the lake (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth") and passed through a 63 micrometer mesh.
Total nitrogen concentration measured in a sample integrated through the euphotic zone (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth").
Total phosphorus concentration measured in a sample integrated through the euphotic zone (defined as "IntegratedSamplingDepth").
Depth to which the zooplankton net was lowered to collect the zooplankton sample.
Total dry mass of zooplankton, as measured in a zooplankton tow taken through the entire water column. See ZooplanktonDepth for the depth to which the zooplankton net was lowered.

dataTable.entityDescription: Discharge data from Acton Lake's main inflowing streams

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date and time on which sample was collected. Time is recorded in Eastern Standard Time.
